===1983=== * May 2 - seven tornadoes touched down in [[Southern Ontario]], mainly in [[Lambton County]] and [[Toronto]]. It caused C$22.2 million in damages and injured 14 people; no fatalities occurred.<ref name="Year1989"/><ref name="30years">{{cite news|last1=Jeffrey|first1=Tara|title=Reece's Corners hardest hit by devastating storm|url=http://www.theobserver.ca/2013/05/01/reeces-corners-hardest-hit-by|accessdate=August 14, 2016|agency=Sarnia Observer|publisher=Postmedia Network|date=May 2, 2013}}</ref> :*[[Walpole Island First Nation|Walpole Island]] saw an F2 tornado, which injured one person. It lasted {{convert|15|km|abbr=on}} on the ground and caused C$1 million in damages.<ref name="Year1989"/><ref name="30years"/> :*[[Plympton–Wyoming|Reece's Corners]] had the strongest tornado, rated an F4. 13 people were injured and many more left homeless. The F4 tornado was on the ground for {{convert|30|km|abbr=on}}, and was up to {{convert|400|m|abbr=on}} in width. Damages were [[Canadian dollar|C$]]20.0 million,<ref name="Year1989"/> with 15 to 25 buildings destroyed. Winds topped out near {{convert|400|kph|abbr=on}}.<ref name="30years"/> :*[[Kettleby, Ontario|Kettleby]] was hit with an F2 tornado that lasted {{convert|10.5|km|abbr=on}} on the ground; no major damage or injuries were reported.<ref name="Year1989"/><ref name="30years"/> :*[[Rexdale]], a informally-defined district of Toronto, saw three F0s. They lasted on the ground from {{convert|5.87|to|9.93|km|abbr=on}}. One caused C$1.2 million in damages. No injuries were reported.<ref name="Year1989"/> *July 8 - a large tornado touched down near [[Blackfoot, Alberta]].<ref>[https://archive.is/20130101120336/http://atlas.nrcan.gc.ca/auth/english/maps/environment/naturalhazards/naturalhazards1999/majortornadoes/tornado_alberta.jpg/image_view ]</ref>
===1984=== * June 29 - a tornado touched down near [[Athabasca, Alberta]], destroying granaries and farm equipment. One person suffered serious injuries. * May 12 - a small tornado touched down near the town of [[Whitewood, Saskatchewan]]. * June 18 - a tornado struck [[Eastern Ontario]] near the town of [[Westport, Ontario|Westport]]. It severely damaged a small group of buildings. * July 8 - a tornado was confirmed near the towns of [[St. Claude, Manitoba|St. Claude]] and [[Rosenort, Manitoba]], just east of [[Winnipeg]]. * July 15 - tornadoes touched down in the Pontiac and [[Gatineau, Quebec]] regions. Many buildings were damaged, and cottages completely destroyed. 38 people were injured by flying debris.<ref name=Quebec>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmos.ca/CB/cb210103.pdf|title=Canadian Meteorological and Oceanographic Society - 404 - Not Found|author=|date=|work=cmos.ca|accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref> * August 14 - a tornado hit the north part of [[Toronto, Ontario]], causing millions in damage.<ref name=Quebec/> * September 2 - six confirmed tornadoes touched down in [[Ontario]], known as the [[Southwest Ontario Tornado Outbreak of 1984]]. Most were near the city of [[London, Ontario|London]]. 30 people were injured.
===1985=== * May 20 - an F0 tornado touched down near [[Saint-Raphaël, Quebec|St Raphael de Bellechasse, Quebec]]. * May 31 - an F4 tornado hit [[Barrie, Ontario]], becoming known as the "Barrie" Tornado Outbreak of 1985. It was part of the bigger [[1985 United States–Canada tornado outbreak]]. There were 13 confirmed tornado touchdowns in the province. Twelve people were killed, eight in Barrie alone, and hundreds injured. The tornado destroyed more than 300 buildings, and damaged another 100, leaving 800 homeless. The cost was estimated at over $100 million. Another four people were killed by a tornado that struck close to [[Grand Valley, Ontario|Grand Valley]], [[Orangeville, Ontario|Orangeville]] and [[Tottenham, Ontario|Tottenham]]. That tornado had a touchdown path length of over {{convert|100|km|mi|abbr=on}}. Another confirmed F0 tornado hit the [[Leamington, Ontario|Leamington]] area, as part of the outbreak. * June 18 - an F3 tornado was confirmed in the town of [[Saint-Sylvère, Quebec]]. * July 6 - an F1 tornado hit the communities of [[Lacolle, Quebec|Lacolle]] and [[Hemmingford, Quebec (village)|Hemmingford]]. * July 7 - an F1 tornado hit the Meadowvale area of [[Mississauga, Ontario]], injuring 10 and causing $400,000 damage. * September 7 - a tornado touched down near [[Big Rideau Lake]], Ontario. The storm killed one person when it overturned a houseboat cruising on the lake.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmos.ca/CB/cb210305.pdf|title=Canadian Meteorological and Oceanographic Society - 404 - Not Found|author=|date=|work=cmos.ca|accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref> * October 4 - a weak tornado touched down in [[Wheatley, Ontario]].
===1986=== * June 1 - three tornadoes touched down in [[Saskatoon, Saskatchewan]]. There were no official ratings given for the tornadoes, although some damage indicated F3 strength winds. Roofs were thrown off houses and a warehouse was destroyed. No one was injured, and damage was estimated at over $1 million. *June 16 - severe storms produced an F3 tornado that travelled from [[Minden Hills|Brady Lake]] to [[Hastings Highlands|Maynooth, Ontario]]. Two other tornadoes were also reported.<ref name=Ontario>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmos.ca/CB/cb240104.pdf|title=Canadian Meteorological and Oceanographic Society - 404 - Not Found|author=|date=|work=cmos.ca|accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref> * June 16 - an F3 tornado was confirmed near Lac Gareau, Quebec. It severely damaged summer chalets and overturned a truck. Two other tornadoes were reported further east. This was from the same weather system that had affected Ontario earlier in the day.<ref name=Ontario/> * June 18 - two tornadoes touched down near [[High Prairie, Alberta]], tossing farm equipment and tearing the roof off a house.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1iNlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ZYgNAAAAIBAJ&pg=6342,1944645&dq=edmonton%20tornado&hl=en|title=Edmonton Journal - Google News Archive Search|author=|date=|work=google.com|accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref> * June 24 - a tornado touched down in [[Tingwick, Quebec]], damaging 12 properties.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8GNhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EqYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=830,2788720&dq=1950%20regina%20tornado&hl=en|title=The Montreal Gazette - Google News Archive Search|author=|date=|work=google.com|accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref> * June 30 - one tornado touched down near [[Stirling, Alberta]] near [[Lethbridge]], and another tore through [[Cayley, Alberta|Cayley]], {{convert|60|km|abbr=on}} south of [[Calgary]]. They destroyed a storage shed, tossed a van across the yard, and hurled a large horse against a barbed wire fence. No injuries were reported.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=FIlWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=XEENAAAAIBAJ&pg=3921,3909924&dq=tornadoes%20in%20alberta&hl=en%7Caccessdate=17|title=The Leader-Post - Google News Archive Search|author=|date=|work=google.com|accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref> * July 9 - three tornadoes briefly touched down throughout [[Central Alberta]]. Two were spotted near [[Penhold]] and one reported south of [[Sylvan Lake, Alberta|Sylvan Lake]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=54hWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WkENAAAAIBAJ&pg=1718,2001881&dq=tornadoes%20in%20alberta&hl=en%7Caccessdate=17|title=The Leader-Post - Google News Archive Search|author=|date=|work=google.com|accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref> * July 15 - one person was killed from an F0 tornado near [[Maniwaki, Quebec]]. * July 29 - four tornadoes touched down in central Saskatchewan, causing minimal damage.<ref name=Ontario/>
===1987=== * May 28 - an F0 tornado struck the community of Glen-Sutton, Quebec.<ref name="Que2000">{{cite web|url=http://www.climat-quebec.qc.ca/home.php?id=p23&mpn=ev_mto_sig&lg=en|title=Centre de Ressources en Impacts et Adaptation au Climat et à ses Changements, Climat-Québec|first=Gouvernement du Canada, Environnement Canada, Région du Québec, Sciences atmosphériques et enjeux|last=environnementaux|date=|work=climat-quebec.qc.ca|accessdate=February 9, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140320173057/http://www.climat-quebec.qc.ca/home.php?id=p23&mpn=ev_mto_sig&lg=en|archivedate=March 20, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> * June 8 - an F1 tornado was confirmed near the town of [[Fort-Coulonge, Quebec]], causing minor damage. * July 22 - an F1 tornado was confirmed in [[Allan Water (Ontario)|Foam Lake Ontario]]. It was the only known tornado in Ontario that year.<ref>http://highwaysandhailstones.com/tornado-map/july-22-1987-foam-lake-f1/</ref> * July 26 - an F1 twister was confirmed near the town of [[Kinnear's Mills, Quebec]]. * July 31 - one of Canada's deadliest tornadoes, an F4, ripped through the eastern part of [[Edmonton]], and parts of neighbouring [[Leduc County]] and [[Strathcona County]]. Known as the [[Edmonton tornado]], it left 27 dead and 253 injured. It was the second deadliest tornado in Canadian history. Seven other tornadoes were also confirmed around in the [[Edmonton Capital Region|Edmonton Area]] and [[Central Alberta]] on the same day; a F1 in southeast Edmonton, F2 near [[Beaumont, Alberta|Beaumont]], a F2 between [[Millet, Alberta|Millet]] and [[Vegreville]],<ref name="web.archive.org">{{cite web|title=The Edmonton Tornado - Environment Canada (archive.org)|url=http://www.mb.ec.gc.ca/air/summersevere/edtornado.en.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021115073531/http://www.mb.ec.gc.ca/air/summersevere/edtornado.en.html|archivedate=2002-11-15}}</ref> causing $40,000 in damages. Four were given an F0 rating.<ref name="web.archive.org"/><ref name="CNTD-VT">{{cite web|title=Canadian National Tornado Database: Verified Events (1980-2009) - Public|url=http://open.canada.ca/data/en/dataset/a720afb1-c271-4fbc-b55c-7d242e1701b6|website=Open Canada|publisher=Environment Canada|accessdate=21 August 2016}}</ref><ref name="Edmonton Other">{{cite web|title=Chapter 3 -J Other tornadoes in greater Edmonton|url=https://sites.google.com/a/ualberta.ca/tornado/home/chapt4|website=A Commemorative Reflection On The Edmonton Tornado And Hail|accessdate=23 June 2016}}</ref>
===1988=== * May 1 - a weak unconfirmed tornado grazed eastern [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]].
===1989=== * June 19 - eight tornadoes touched down over central Saskatchewan, with winds gusting up to {{convert|130|km/h|abbr=on}}. Hail shredded crops near [[Blaine Lake]]. * July 27 - a series of severe thunderstorms spawned an F1 tornado in the west end of [[Edmonton, Alberta]].<ref name="Year1989"/><ref name="F-rating">{{cite web|title=July 1989 Tornado|url=http://www.recordmeteo.com/tornado-canada/Tornado-Alberta-1989-7-27-en-118.html|website=Record Meteo|accessdate=1 August 2016}}</ref> The tornado injured two people, and damaged buildings and uprooted trees and power lines. It caused $500,000 in damages.<ref name="Year1989"/><ref name="TWN-1">{{cite web|title=On This Day (1989 Edmonton Tornado)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7vEWhAYZ1UI|website=Youtube|publisher=The Weather Network|accessdate=1 August 2016|format=Video|date=27 July 1993}}</ref> * August 14 - three tornadoes touched down in the province of [[New Brunswick]]. One hit the town of Carlisle, where trees were uprooted and a barn was destroyed. 22 out of 24 glass storm windows stored inside the barn were left undamaged. * November 16 - an F2 tornado caused $2 million in damage in the community of [[Mont-Saint-Hilaire, Quebec]].
== 1990s ==
===1990=== * June 28 - a large tornado touched down south of [[Saskatoon, Saskatchewan]]. * August 28 - [[Southern Ontario]] was hit by three tornadoes, in an outbreak associated with the [[1990 Plainfield tornado]]. The strongest was an F3, which hit near the [[Port Stanley, Ontario|Port Stanley]] area, destroying 10 homes in Frome, and barns near [[St. Thomas, Ontario|St. Thomas]] and [[Delaware, Ontario|Delaware]], killing several horses. An F2 tornado also struck [[Komoka, Ontario|Komoka]], near [[London, Ontario|London]], destroying a church. An F1 tornado touched down near the small town of [[Clarington|Kendal]], just north of [[Newtonville, Ontario|Newtonville]]. Only six minor injuries were reported.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elgin.ca/ElginCounty/CulturalServices/Archives/tweedsmuir/Middlemarch%20Vol%202/page%20150%20-%20160.pdf |format=PDF |title=Built to Last |website=Elgin.ca |accessdate=2017-02-24}}</ref>
===1991=== * March 27 - an early season tornado struck [[Sarnia, Ontario]], causing over $25 million in damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cdd.publicsafety.gc.ca/dtpg-eng.aspx?cultureCode=en-Ca&provinces=9&normalizedCostYear=1&dynamic=false&eventId=129|title=Canadian Disaster Database|first=Public Safety Canada|last=Government of Canada|date=September 13, 2013|work=publicsafety.gc.ca|accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref> * August 27 - an F3 tornado touched down in the [[Mauricie]] region. The town of [[Maskinongé, Quebec|Maskinongé]] was hardest hit among three communities, with 60% of its buildings damaged. Fifteen people were injured and the estimated damage cost was upwards of $25 million.<ref name="publicsafety1">[https://web.archive.org/web/20100323171952/http://www.publicsafety.gc.ca/res/em/nh/to/to-sig-eng.aspx ]</ref>
===1992=== * June 24 - tornadoes, large hail and torrential downpours affected [[southern Manitoba]]. Tennis ball sized hail fell near [[Morden, Manitoba|Morden]] and winds gusting to {{convert|154|km/h|abbr=on}} were recorded at [[Pilot Mound, Manitoba|Pilot Mound]]. There were five confirmed tornado touchdowns and numerous [[funnel cloud]]s in Manitoba that day. There was some very crisp video footage of one rope tornado tearing up farmland near [[Portage la Prairie]]. The region had been affected by severe weather the day before as well.
===1993=== * July 29 - a series of violent thunderstorms tracked across [[Central Alberta]], spawning three tornadoes. The strongest of these was an F3 in [[Holden, Alberta|Holden]], {{convert|90|km|abbr=on}} east of Edmonton. An F0 touched down in near [[Falun, Alberta|Falun]], east of [[Pigeon Lake (Alberta)|Pigeon Lake]], and an F1 tornado was reported {{Convert|60|km|abbr=on}} northeast of [[Lac La Biche, Alberta|Lac La Biche]].
===1994=== * July 9 - one person was killed when an F2 tore through the town of [[Saint-Charles-sur-Richelieu, Quebec]]. Three other people were injured, and about a dozen homes were damaged. * August 4 - an F3 tornado touched down in [[Aylmer, Quebec]] across the river from [[Ottawa]], injuring 15 people. The tornado path was {{convert|8|km|abbr=on}} long and caused major damage to a downtown residential subdivision, including homes destroyed. A second tornado had previously touched down just across the [[Ottawa River]] in [[Carp, Ontario|Carp]]. In Quebec, other tornadoes touched down near [[Wentworth-Nord, Quebec|Laurel]] and [[Rawdon, Quebec|Rawdon]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20030821125801/http://www.criacc.qc.ca/climat/suivi/tornade_f.html]</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Aylmer residents on 1994 tornado: 'It is impossible to forget' |url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/aylmer-residents-on-1994-tornado-it-is-impossible-to-forget-1.2724238 |website=cbc.ca |publisher=CBC |accessdate=2018-09-26}}</ref> * August 27 - a F4 tornado hit rural farmland near [[Municipality of Killarney-Turtle Mountain|Turtle Mountain, Manitoba]]. Devastation was especially visible at Mayfair [[Hutterite]] Colony, and there was well over $1 million in damage. There were no injuries or deaths.
===1995=== * June 20 - thunderstorms rumbled for seven hours over Manitoba, producing {{convert|90|km/h|abbr=on}} winds which blew trees and power lines over. The storm produced a weak tornado. * July 15 - a large progressive [[derecho]] thunderstorm produced severe winds over an expansive area of the central [[Great Lakes]] and [[New England]] overnight. It also contained at least six tornadoes that hit [[Central Ontario]], most centred on or to the north of the [[Kawartha Lakes (Ontario)|Kawartha Lakes]]. The strongest was an F2 tornado that destroyed a marina at [[Selwyn, Ontario|Bridgenorth]] and overturned a houseboat on [[Lake Chemong]], trapping 20 occupants for a few hours until they were rescued, just north of [[Peterborough, Ontario|Peterborough]]. One person was killed in Bridgenorth. * July 26 - a tornado in [[Fredericton, New Brunswick]] took the roof off a government building and damaged a tennis court dome. * August 14 - a tornado touched down near [[Barrie, Ontario]]. * August 29 - several farms were destroyed when a tornado lasting a couple of minutes affected [[Spring Valley, Saskatchewan]], near [[Moose Jaw]].
===1996=== * April 20 - [[1996 Southern Ontario tornadoes|Multiple tornadoes]] hit [[Grey County|Grey]], [[Wellington County, Ontario|Wellington]] and [[Dufferin County|Dufferin]] counties. Two F3 class tornadoes touched down in Grey County ([[Williamsford, Ontario|Williamsford]]), Wellington County and Dufferin County. Significant property damage occurred; nine people were injured by the two tornadoes. * May 20 - a strong thunderstorm damaged one of the four screens of a drive-in theatre at [[Thorold, Ontario]] in the [[Regional Municipality of Niagara|Niagara Region]]. Coincidentally, this drive-in was planning to show the movie ''[[Twister (1996 film)|Twister]]'' that evening. Eyewitnesses reported seeing a small funnel cloud, but the physical evidence was inconclusive. Distorted and exaggerated media reports of this event abound; most claimed that the storm blew down the screen while ''Twister'' was being shown on it. The storm actually took place before sundown. However, a small tornado did touch down in [[Stoney Creek, Ontario|Stoney Creek]] that same evening. * July 4 - an estimated nine tornadoes touched down in the [[Saskatoon]], [[Maymont, Saskatchewan|Maymont]] and [[Osler, Saskatchewan]] areas. An F3 was measured in the Maymont area, destroying power lines. Homes and property were damaged in the Osler area. Wind gusts in Saskatoon reached {{convert|120|km/h|abbr=on}} and {{convert|141|km/h|abbr=on}}, damaging many trees and properties on the east end of the city. A drive-in theatre and a nightclub on the eastern outskirts of the city were also heavily damaged; the movie that was going to be shown at the drive-in that night was ''Twister''.
===1997=== * June 24 - [[Lantz, Nova Scotia]], F0 tornado touched down in a local ball field at approximately 4:45 pm [[Atlantic Time Zone|ADT]] ([[UTC−03:00]]). Golf ball sized hail and intense lightning were also reported with this storm. * July 2 - [[1997 Southeast Michigan tornado outbreak|Southeast Michigan tornado outbreak]] in F1, F2, F3 [[Windsor, Ontario|Windsor]] and surrounding areas. See article for more in-depth information. * July 4 - an F2 tornado touched down near [[Grand Falls, New Brunswick]]. A roof was torn off a building, and farmers' fields were ripped up. The same line of storms also dropped an F2 tornado in [[Matapédia, Quebec|Matapédia]] (New Brunswick/Quebec border), where a couple of barns were destroyed.
===1998=== * June 2 - during a wider severe weather outbreak ([[Derecho|derecho thunderstorm]]) that struck [[Southern Ontario]] in the mid-afternoon, an F1 tornado descended near Holbrook around 3:50 pm EDT (UTC−04:00) and travelled southeastward to [[Norwich, Ontario|Norwich]], damaging many buildings, including a church. There were also tornado reports in [[Elmvale, Ontario|Elmvale]] and [[Dunnville, Ontario|Dunnville]], and several reports of funnel clouds, hail, and high winds. * July 10 - an F2 tornado touched down in Charleston, New Brunswick, leaving a {{convert|90|m|abbr=on}} by {{convert|7|km|abbr=on}} path of damage. A mobile home was thrown {{convert|30|m|abbr=on}} and totally destroyed. There were minor injuries to the residents in the home. * July 19 - a weak tornado hit [[Daysland, Alberta]], about {{convert|50|km|abbr=on}} east of [[Camrose, Alberta|Camrose]]. It damaged power lines, knocking out power to surrounding communities. * August 11 - a small F1 tornado went through part of [[Saint-Émile, Quebec City]], in the suburbs of [[Quebec City]]. It overturned a shed and caused a citywide electricity loss when a garage was slammed into an electric pole.
===1999=== * May 8 - a tornado over [[Hull, Quebec]] caused $2M damage and tore roofs off buildings. It was caused by the same system that produced the [[1999 Oklahoma tornado outbreak]] between May 3 and May 8. It was the second significant tornado in the [[Gatineau|Hull-Gatineau]] area in five years. * May 18 - three tornadoes touched down close to the western limits of [[Saskatoon, Saskatchewan]]. The supercell associated with the tornadoes pelted the city with quarter-sized hail, wind gusts of nearly {{convert|100|km/h|abbr=on}}, and over {{convert|2|in|abbr=on|order=flip}} of rain fell from the half-hour storm. * July 6 - a [[Centre-du-Québec|Bois-Francs, Quebec]] region tornado left 4,000 without power and 200 in need of temporary shelter in [[Berthierville]], [[Yamaska, Quebec|Yamaska]] and [[Drummondville]]. Environment Canada records show one person was killed in the event.<ref name="publicsafety1"/> * August 4 - an F2 tornado with a twisting but narrow path caused damage in the rural north end of [[Burlington, Ontario]], relocating a [[motorhome]] {{convert|2|km|abbr=on}} from where it was parked. The tornado track was over {{convert|10|km|abbr=on}} long. * August 18 - a small tornado struck [[Pugwash, Nova Scotia]], causing some localized structural damage. There were no serious injuries.
== 2000s == ''For tornadoes after 2000, see [[list of 21st-century Canadian tornadoes and tornado outbreaks]]''
===2000=== *May 5 - an F0 tornado was confirmed near Hazzards Corners, Ontario, {{convert|8|km|abbr=on}} northeast of [[Madoc, Ontario|Madoc]]. It left a {{convert|10|km|abbr=on}} long path, causing minor damage to a house and knocking over approximately 100 trees.<ref name=Ont2000>[https://web.archive.org/web/20020402082919/http://www.ontarioweather.com/specials/database/TornadoQuery.asp]</ref> *May 9 - two [[anticyclonic tornado]]es touched down in [[Southern Ontario]], causing minor damage. The first was given an F0 rating, and occurred north of [[Amherstburg]]. Multiple trees were knocked over along a {{convert|7|km|abbr=on}} path. The second tornado, an F1, touched down in Malden Centre. It tore the roof from a storage shed, and knocked over a large shipping container along a {{convert|1|km|abbr=on}} path. No injuries were reported with either storm.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yorku.ca/pat/research/dsills/surveys/9may00/survey.html|title=9 May 2000 - Storm Damage Survey|first=David|last=Sills|date=|work=yorku.ca|accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref> *May 23 - an F2 tornado touched down near [[Southwest Middlesex, Ontario|Appin, Ontario]], damaging a pig barn and killing several pigs. Multiple homes also sustained damage, and [[Hydroelectricity|hydro]] poles were snapped. No injuries were reported.<ref name=Ont2000/> *May 24 - a confirmed F1 tornado hit [[Gloucester, Ontario]], a suburb within the city of [[Ottawa]]. It snapped trees, tore the roof off a house and ripped the canopy from a gas station.<ref name=2Ont2000>{{cite web|url=http://highwaysandhailstones.com/tornadoes-in-ontario/|title=Highways & Hailstones - TORNADOES IN ONTARIO|author=|date=|work=highwaysandhailstones.com|accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref> *June 22 - an F0 tornado was confirmed near the town of [[Quyon, Quebec]].<ref name="Que2000"/> *July 14 - an F3 tornado struck Green Acres Campground in [[Pine Lake, Alberta]]. Known as the [[Pine Lake tornado]], it killed 12 people and caused over $13 million in damage. It was ranked as the fourth deadliest tornado in Canadian history. *July 17 - three tornadoes were confirmed in [[Ontario]] after several [[supercell]] thunderstorms developed over the province. An F2 tornado formed over the city of [[Guelph]], lasting approximately 23 minutes and leaving a path of damage {{convert|13|km|abbr=on}} long. Damage was estimated at over $2 million and one minor injury was reported. The same storm also produced a second, unrated tornado near [[Waterdown, Ontario|Waterdown]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yorku.ca/pat/research/dsills/surveys/17Jul00/Guelph/survey.html|title=17 July 2000 - Storm Damage Survey|first=David|last=Sills|date=|work=yorku.ca|accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref> The third tornado, an F1, occurred in [[Simcoe County]], near the town of [[Tay, Ontario|Melduf]]. It snapped and uprooted trees, and caused minor crop damage. An aluminum shed was destroyed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yorku.ca/pat/research/dsills/surveys/17Jul00/Melduf/survey.html|title=17 July 2000 - Storm Damage Survey|first=David|last=Sills|date=|work=yorku.ca|accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref> *July 18 - an F0 tornado touched down near [[Saint-Jean-Chrysostome, Lévis, Quebec|Saint-Jean-Chrysostome, Quebec]].<ref name="Que2000"/> *July 23 - an F3 tornado touched down and destroyed one home and tossed farm equipment near [[Marwayne, Alberta]], {{convert|35|km|abbr=on}} northwest of [[Lloydminster]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/story/2000/07/24/rancher000724.html|title=Rancher survives tornado|author=|date=|work=cbc.ca|accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref> *July 26 - a tornado touched down briefly near [[Wabamun, Alberta]], about {{convert|70|km|abbr=on}} west of [[Edmonton]], causing minor damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apsts.alberta.ca/uploads/1103/2011bemstudenthandou62900.pdf |format=PDF |title=Alberta Emergency Management Agency : Basic Emergency Management Course |website=Apsts.alberta.ca |accessdate=2017-02-24}}</ref> *August 1 - a tornado struck [[Viking, Alberta]]. *August 6 - a tornado touched down near [[Elnora, Alberta]], southeast of Pine Lake. The tornado occurred while people were gathering for a memorial service in Pine Lake for those who died in the Pine Lake tornado just a few weeks earlier. *August 9 - a tornado was confirmed near [[Sangudo, Alberta]]. *August 9 - an F1 tornado touched down near [[Tilbury, Ontario]], destroying a barn and causing heavy damage to two farmhouses. No injuries were reported.<ref name=2Ont2000/>

{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Plasmodium'' species}} {{Taxobox | name = List of ''Plasmodium'' species | domain = [[Eukaryota]] | unranked_regnum = [[SAR supergroup|SAR]] | unranked_superphylum = [[Alveolata]] | phylum = [[Apicomplexa]] | classis = [[Aconoidasida]] | subclassis = [[Haemosporidiasina]] | ordo = [[Haemosporida]] | subordo = [[Laveraniina]] | familia = [[Plasmodiidae]] | genus = ''[[Plasmodium]]'' | subdivision_ranks = Species | subdivision = see text }} The genus ''Plasmodium'' is a member of the order [[Haemosporidia]]. It is the largest genus within this order and currently consists of over 250 species. They cause [[malaria]] in many different [[vertebrates]]. The species in this genus are entirely [[parasitic]] with part of their life cycle spent in a vertebrate host and another in an invertebrate host - usually a [[mosquito]]. Vertebrates infected by members of this genus include mammals, birds and reptiles. Host range among the mammalian orders is non uniform. At least 29 species infect non human [[primates]]; [[rodents]] outside the tropical parts of [[Africa]] are rarely affected; a few species are known to infect [[bat]]s, [[porcupine]]s and [[squirrel]]s; [[carnivore]]s, [[insectivore]]s and [[marsupial]]s are not known to act as hosts. The listing of host species among the reptiles has rarely been attempted. Ayala in 1978 listed 156 published accounts on 54 valid species and subspecies between 1909 and 1975.{{cite journal | doi = 10.1111/j.1550-7408.1978.tb03874.x | author = Ayala S.C. | year = 1978 | title = Checklist, host index, and annotated bibliography of ''Plasmodium'' from reptiles | url = | journal = J. Eukaryot. Microbiol. | volume = 25 | issue = 1| pages = 87–100 }} The regional breakdown was Africa: 30 reports on 9 species; [[Australia]], [[Asia]] & [[Oceania]]: 12 reports on 6 species and 2 subspecies; [[Americas]]: 116 reports on 37 species. ==Diagnostic criteria of the order Haemosporida== Currently there are ~550 species recognised in this order organised into 17 genera.{{cite journal |doi=10.1073/pnas.1311016110 |pmid=24101466 |pmc=3808598 |title=High diversity of West African bat malaria parasites and a tight link with rodent Plasmodium taxa |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences |volume=110 |issue=43 |pages=17415–9 |year=2013 |last1=Schaer |first1=J |last2=Perkins |first2=S. L |last3=Decher |first3=J |last4=Leendertz |first4=F. H |last5=Fahr |first5=J |last6=Weber |first6=N |last7=Matuschewski |first7=K }} The diagnostic criteria of this family are: * [[macrogamete]]s and [[microgamont]]s develop independently * [[Syzygy (biology)|syzygy]] is absent * [[microgametocyte]] produces 8 flagellated [[microgamete]]s * [[zygote]] is motile (known as an [[ookinete]]) * [[conoid]] present in ookinete stage only * [[sporozoites]] naked in [[oocyst]] (that is without a sporocyst) * heteroxenous: [[Protozoal merogony|merogony]] and [[gamogony]] occur in [[vertebrate]] host and fertilization and [[sporogony]] in definitive host (a blood sucking [[insect]]) * [[hemozoin]] pigment produced in some genera (including ''Plasmodium'') ==Diagnostic criteria of the genus ''Plasmodium''== * [[Protozoal merogony|Merogony]] occurs both in [[erythrocyte]]s and other tissues * [[Merozoite]]s, [[schizont]]s or [[gametocyte]]s can be seen within erythrocytes and may displace the host nucleus * Merozoites have a "signet-ring" appearance due to a large vacuole that forces the parasite’s nucleus to one pole * Schizonts are round to oval inclusions that contain the deeply staining merozoites * Forms gamonts in erythrocytes * Gametocytes are 'halter-shaped' similar to ''[[Haemoproteus]]'' but the pigment granules are more confined * [[Hemozoin]] is present * [[Vector (epidemiology)|Vector]]s are either [[mosquito]]es or sandflies (''[[Lutzomyia]]''). * [[Vertebrate]] hosts include [[mammal]]s, [[bird]]s and [[reptile]]s ===Note=== Mammalian erythrocytes do not possess a [[Cell nucleus|nucleus]]. Although it has been suggested that the nucleus was lost in the erythrocytes better to enable them to traverse capillaries evidence for this is lacking. It appears that this loss along with the mitochondria that the erythrocytes also lose may protect the erythrocytes against oxidative stress.{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/iub.490 |pmid=21698761 |title=Red blood cell extrudes nucleus and mitochondria against oxidative stress |journal=IUBMB Life |volume=63 |issue=7 |pages=560–5 |year=2011 |last1=Zhang |first1=Zhong-Wei |last2=Cheng |first2=Jian |last3=Xu |first3=Fei |last4=Chen |first4=Yang-Er |last5=Du |first5=Jun-Bo |last6=Yuan |first6=Ming |last7=Zhu |first7=Feng |last8=Xu |first8=Xiao-Chao |last9=Yuan |first9=Shu }} ==Subgenera== The full taxonomic name of a species includes the subgenus but this is often omitted in practice. The full name indicates some features of the morphology and type of host species. Sixteen subgenera are currently recognised. The avian species were discovered soon after the description of ''P. falciparum'' and a variety of generic names were created. These were subsequently placed into the genus ''Plasmodium'' although some workers continued to use the genera ''Laverinia'' and ''[[Proteosoma]]'' for ''P. falciparum'' and the avian species respectively. The 5th and 6th Congresses of Malaria held at [[Istanbul]] (1953) and [[Lisbon]] (1958) respectively recommended the creation and use of subgenera in this genus. ''Laverinia'' was applied to the species infecting humans and ''Haemamoeba'' to those infecting lizards and birds. This proposal was not universally accepted. Bray in 1955 proposed a definition for the subgenus ''Plasmodium'' and a second for the subgenus ''Laverinia'' in 1958. Garnham described a third subgenus - ''Vinckeia'' - in 1964. In 1963 Corradetti, Garnham and Laird proposed a new classification of the avian malaria parasites. They created four sub-genera - ''Giovannolaia'', ''Haemamoeba'', ''Huffia'' and ''Novyella'' - based on the size of the schizonts, the gametocyte forms and the type of exo-erythrocytic schizogony. Additional subgenera have been created since. The currently recognised subgenera are listed below. ''[[Asiamoeba]]'' Telford 1988
''[[Bennettinia]]'' Valkiūnas 1997Valkiunas G. (1997). Bird Haemosporidia. Institute of Ecology, Vilnius{{page needed|date=June 2018}}
''[[Carinamoeba]]'' Garnham 1966
''[[Giovannolaia]]'' Corradetti, Garnham & Laird 1963{{cite journal |last=Corradetti |first=A. |authorlink= |author2=Garnham, P. C. C. |author3=Laird, M. |year=1963 |title=New classification of the avian malaria parasites |journal=Parassitologia |volume=5 |issue= |pages=1–4 |id= |url= |accessdate= |quote= }}
''[[Haemamoeba]]'' Grassi & Feletti 1890
''[[Huffia]]'' Garnham & Laird 1963
''[[Lacertaemoba]]'' Telford 1988
''[[Laverania]]'' Bray 1958{{cite journal |doi=10.4269/ajtmh.1958.7.20 |pmid=13508992 |title=Studies on Malaria in Chimpanzees |journal=The American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene |volume=7 |issue=1 |pages=20–4 |year=1958 |last1=Bray |first1=R. S }}
''[[Novyella]]'' Corradetti, Garnham & Laird 1963
''[[Nyssorhynchus]]'' Poinar 2005
''[[Ophidiella]]'' Garnham 1966
''[[Papernaia]]'' Landau ''et al'' 2010{{cite journal |doi=10.1051/parasite/2010171003 |pmid=20387732 |title=The sub-genera of Avian ''Plasmodium'' |journal=Parasite |volume=17 |issue=1 |pages=3–7 |year=2010 |last1=Landau |first1=I |last2=Chavatte |first2=J.M |last3=Peters |first3=W |last4=Chabaud |first4=A }}
''[[Paraplasmodium]]'' Telford 1988
''[[Plasmodium]]'' Bray 1963 emend. Garnham 1964
''[[Sauramoeba]]'' Garnham 1966
''[[Vinckeia]]'' Garnham 1964 ==Classification criteria for subgenera== The current classification scheme was developed prior to the widespread use of DNA sequence based taxonomy and is based on host and morphological criteria. ''Plasmodium'' has since been shown to be paraphytic with the genera ''[[Haemoproteus]]'' and ''[[Hepatocystis]]'' (''vide infra''). Revision of this genus will be undertaken once sufficient DNA sequence material is available. This forthcoming reclassification project is not unique to this genus as DNA based taxonomy is revising many traditional groupings of protozoa. The bird infecting taxa can be separated into two groups on the basis of the gametocytes: species with round gametocytes (''Bennettinia'', ''Haemamoeba'') and species with elongated gametocytes (''Giovanniola'', ''Huffia'' and ''Novyella''). The monophyly of the ''Bennettinia'', ''Haemamoeba'' and ''Huffia'' subgenera was subsequently confirmed by molecular studies.{{cite journal |doi=10.1017/S0031182006001922 |pmid=17147839 |title=Morphologically defined subgenera of Plasmodium from avian hosts: Test of monophyly by phylogenetic analysis of two mitochondrial genes |journal=Parasitology |volume=134 |issue=4 |pages=483–90 |year=2006 |last1=Martinsen |first1=E. S |last2=Waite |first2=J. L |last3=Schall |first3=J. J }} The other two genera were found to be paraphytic. The genera were then revised and a new subgenus - ''Papernaia'' - was created. ===Species with mammalian hosts=== ''[[Laverania]]'' Species in this subgenus infect higher primates (including man) and have characteristic sickle shaped female gametocytes. The type species is ''[[Plasmodium falciparum]]''. ''[[Plasmodium]]'' Species infecting higher primates other than those in the subgenus ''Laverania'' are placed in the subgenus ''Plasmodium''. The type species is ''[[Plasmodium malariae]]''. ''[[Vinckeia]]'' Parasites infecting other mammals including lower [[primate]]s ([[lemur]]s and others) are classified in the subgenus ''Vinckeia''. The type species is ''[[Plasmodium bubalis]]''. ===Species with avian hosts=== ''[[Bennettinia]]'' Schizonts contain scant cytoplasm, are often round, do not exceed the size of the host nucleus and stick to it. Gametocytes, while varying in shape tend to be round or oval, do not exceed the size of the nucleus and stick to it. The type species is ''[[Plasmodium juxtanucleare]]''. ''[[Giovannolaia]]'' Schizonts contain plentiful cytoplasm, are larger than the host cell nucleus and frequently displace it. They are found only in mature erythrocytes. Gametocytes are elongated. Exoerythrocytic schizogony occurs in the mononuclear phagocyte system. The type species is ''[[Plasmodium circumflexum]]''. ''[[Haemamoeba]]'' Mature schizonts are larger than the host cell nucleus and commonly displace it. Gametocytes are large, round, oval or irregular in shape and are substantially larger than the host nucleus. The type species is ''[[Plasmodium relictum]]''. ''[[Huffia]]'' Mature schizonts, while varying in shape and size, contain plentiful cytoplasm and are commonly found in immature erythryocytes. Gametocytes are elongated. The type species is ''[[Plasmodium elongatum]]''. ''[[Novyella]]'' Mature schizonts are either smaller than or only slightly larger than the host nucleus. They contain scanty [[cytoplasm]]. Gametocytes are elongated. Sexual stages in this subgenus resemble those of ''[[Haemoproteus]]''. A white/blue globule is present in the cytoplasm. Exoerythrocytic schizogony occurs in the [[mononuclear]] [[phagocyte]] system The type species is ''[[Plasmodium vaughani]]''. ''[[Papernaia]]'' The gametocytes are elongated. The schizonts apically or lateroapically placed and are rounded or irregularly shaped. The host nucleus may be tilted. The type species is ''[[Plasmodium polare]]'' ===Species with reptilian hosts=== Although over 3200 species of lizard have been identified as hosts to ''Plasmodium'' species, only 29 species of snakes have been. All snake infecting species are placed into the subgenus ''Ophidiella''. ''[[Asiamoeba]]'' The schizonts and gametocytes are greatly disparate in size (4 to 15 times). ''[[Carinamoeba]]'' The schizonts are small and give rise to 8 or fewer merozoites. The gametocytes like the schizonts are small. The type species is ''[[Plasmodium minasense]]''. ''[[Lacertaemoba]]'' The schizonts are medium-sized and undergo 3 to 5 nuclear divisions. The gametocytes are medium-sized ''[[Paraplasmodium]]'' The schizonts are of medium size. Exoerythrocytic schizonts may be produced in both fixed and wandering host cells. The gametocytes are large. One species in this sub-genus is capable of merogony in a vector of the ''[[Lutzomyia]]'' genus. ''[[Sauramoeba]]'' Large schizonts giving rise to 12 or more merozoites. The gametocytes like the schizonts are large. The asexual stages tend to disappear from the lymphocytes once the gametocytes appear in the lymphocytes. The type species is ''[[Plasmodium agamae]]''. ''[[Ophidiella]]'' The species in this subgenus infect only [[snake]]s. The type species is ''[[Plasmodium weyoni]]''. ===Species with unknown hosts=== One species has been identified from [[Dominica]]n amber - ''[[Plasmodium dominicum]]''. The vertebrate host of this species is unknown but it seems likely that it may have been a bird. ''[[Nyssorhynchus]]'' The type species is ''[[Plasmodium dominicum]]''. ==Phylogenetics== Although the evolution of this genus has been studied by a number of authors, details are still being elucidated. A brief summary of the pattern that has emerged is as follows: The most basal split in the genus is between the reptile/bird species and the mammalian species. The bird/reptile clade appears to be related to the genera ''[[Haemoproteus]]'', ''[[Leukocytozoon]]'' and ''[[Polychromophilus]]''. The genus ''[[Hepatocystis]]'' appears to have evolved from with the mammalian species clade. Within the mammalian species the subgenus ''Laverinia'' appears to be basal with the subgenus ''Plasmodium'' and the rodent species being sister clades. ''Hepatocystis'' appears to have diverged after the separation of the rodent species. The species infecting lemurs may belong in the subgenus ''Plasmodium'' instead of their current placement within the subgenus ''Vinckeia''. Within the subgenus ''Plasmodium'', ''P. vivax'' groups with an Asian clade which appears to be rooted in Africa. ''P. malaria'' and ''P. ovale'' both belong to an African clade and are more closely related to each other than to ''P. vivax''. Within the subgenus ''Laverinia'' P. falciparum and ''P. reichenowi'' form a clade while the other four known species form a second clade. There are a number of additional species in these taxa that await full description so changes to the branching order are likely. However the overall arrangement outlined above seems to be supported by a number of studies by different authors and is unlikely to change. Given the recently recognised paraphytic nature of several of the taxa above, the introduction of new genera and possibly families in the near future seems highly likely. ===Relations with other Haemosporidian genera=== While most phylogenetic trees have tended to agree that ''Plasmodium'' has descended from ''Leukocytozoon'' or ''Haemoproteus'' like species a Bayesian phylogenetic reconstruction suggests that ''Plasmodium'' may be the ancestral genus that has given rise to ''Haemoproteus'' and other genera. Further study in this area is required. Another Bayesian analysis has suggested the following taxonomy: Mammalian ''Plasmodium'' and ''Hepatocystis'' are sister clades with ''Hepatocystis'' having evolved from within the genus ''Plasmodium''; the bird and reptile species are intermixed and basal to the mammalian ''Plasmodium''/''Hepatocystis'' species; the reptilian/bird ''Plasmodium'' species are a sister clade to the genus ''[[Polychromophilus]]''; ''[[Leukocytozoon]]'' and ''[[Haemoproteus]]'' and sister clades; the ''Leukocytozoon''/''Haemoproteus'' clade is a sister to the ''[[Haemoproteus|Parahaemoproteus]]'' clade; and the ''Parahaemoproteus''/''Haemoproteus''/''Leukocytozoon'' clade is a sister to the reptilian/bird ''Plasmodium''/''Polychromophilus'' clade.{{cite journal |doi=10.1073/pnas.1109153108 |pmid=21730128 |pmc=3156215 |title=Rerooting the evolutionary tree of malaria parasites |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences |volume=108 |issue=32 |pages=13183–7 |year=2011 |last1=Outlaw |first1=Diana C |last2=Ricklefs |first2=Robert E }} This grouping is supported by previous results.{{cite journal |doi=10.1645/0022-3395(2002)088[0972:AMPOMP]2.0.CO;2 |pmid=12435139 |year=2002 |volume=88 |issue=5 |pages=972–8 |journal=Journal of Parasitology |last1=Perkins |first1=Susan L |title=A molecular phylogeny of malarial parasites recovered from cytochrome b gene sequences |last2=Schall |first2=Josj }} A study of DNA sequences suggests that the genus is paraphytic with ''[[Hepatocystis]]'' being related to the mammalian species and ''[[Polychromophilus]]'' being related to the reptile species.{{cite journal |doi=10.1186/1475-2875-11-53 |pmid=22356874 |pmc=3342143 |title=The evolutionary host switches of Polychromophilus: A multi-gene phylogeny of the bat malaria genus suggests a second invasion of mammals by a haemosporidian parasite |journal=Malaria Journal |volume=11 |pages=53 |year=2012 |last1=Witsenburg |first1=Fardo |last2=Salamin |first2=Nicolas |last3=Christe |first3=Philippe }} This study also supports the ancestor of ''Plasmodium'' being a ''[[Leucocytozoon]]'' like species and that ''Plasmodium'' is more closely related to the ''[[Haemoproteus]]'' - specifically the subgenus ''[[Haemoproteus|Parahaemoproteus]]'' - than to ''Leucocytozoon''. A paper by Blanquart and GascuelBlanquart S, Gascuel O (2011) Mitochondrial genes support a common origin of rodent malaria parasites and ''Plasmodium falciparum''s relatives infecting great apes. BMC Evol Biol 11(1):70 examined ''Plasmodium'' 84 mitochondrial sequences and included ''[[Hepatocystis]]'', ''[[Haemoproteus]]'' and ''[[Leukocytozoon]]'' sequences. The results agree with the previous analyses showing that ''Hepatocystis'', ''Haemoproteus'' and ''Plasmodium'' appear to be derived from a ''Leukocytozoon'' ancestor. ''Hepatocystis'' appears to be a sister group to the great ape-rodent clade with the lower primate clade being ancestral to all three. In terms of ''Plasmodium'' subgenera they suggest that the subgenus ''[[Plasmodium]]'' is ancestral to both ''[[Laverania]]'' and ''[[Vinckeia]]''. A study of parasites infecting bats found that the bats were infected by species of the genera ''Hepatocystis'', ''Plasmodium'', ''Polychomophilus'' and ''Nycteria''. A phylogenetic tree which included these genera along with ''Haemoproteus'' and ''Leukocytozoon'' species was examined. As before ''Leukocytozoon'' was basal in this tree. The next clade to diverge was that of the ''Haemoproteus'' species. The remaining genera lay within the currently established genus ''Plasmodium''. The authors suggested that the origin of the ''Plasmodium''/''Hepatocystis'' clade was likely to have been in Africa. Within this genus the first to diverge were the avian and reptile species. The next clade to diverge was that of the ''Polychomophilus'' species. This was followed in branching order by the ''Nycteria'' species. The subgenus ''Laverinia'' was the next to diverge followed by the subgenus ''Vinckeia''. The crown of the tree was formed by the subgenus ''Plasmodium'' and the genus ''Hepatocytis''. This tree did not support the inclusion of ''P. ovale'' in the subgenus ''Vinckeia'' but agreed with previous analyses suggesting that ''P. malaria'' is more closely related to the Asian clade than ''P. ovale'' is. Several of the bat infecting ''Plasmodium'' species appear to be related to the rodent species. Bats appear to have evolved ~{{Ma|66}} in Africa{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/molbev/msi180 |pmid=15930153 |title=A Nuclear DNA Phylogenetic Perspective on the Evolution of Echolocation and Historical Biogeography of Extant Bats (Chiroptera) |journal=Molecular Biology and Evolution |volume=22 |issue=9 |pages=1869–86 |year=2005 |last1=Eick |first1=Geeta N |last2=Jacobs |first2=David S |last3=Matthee |first3=Conrad A }} which - assuming that the phylogenetic tree in Schaer ''et al'' is correct - places an upper limit on the date for the evolution of the mammalian species of ''Plasmodium''. Another study of the genera ''Leucocytozoon'', ''Haemoproteus'', ''Parahaemoproteus'', ''Polychromophilus'' and ''Plasmodium'' found that ''Leucocytozoon'' occupied a basal position and that ''Polychromophilus'' and ''Plasmodium'' were sister clades.{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.ympev.2015.09.003 |pmid=26364971 |title=Phylogeny of haemosporidian blood parasites revealed by a multi-gene approach |journal=Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution |volume=94 |issue=Pt A |pages=221–31 |year=2016 |last1=Borner |first1=Janus |last2=Pick |first2=Christian |last3=Thiede |first3=Jenny |last4=Kolawole |first4=Olatunji Matthew |last5=Kingsley |first5=Manchang Tanyi |last6=Schulze |first6=Jana |last7=Cottontail |first7=Veronika M |last8=Wellinghausen |first8=Nele |last9=Schmidt-Chanasit |first9=Jonas |last10=Bruchhaus |first10=Iris |last11=Burmester |first11=Thorsten }} A study of ''Polychromophilus'' species found that this genus lies within the avian/reptile clade of ''Plasmodium'' species. A study of mitochondrial, plastid and nuclear genes of the species ''Plasmodium odocoilei'' suggests that this species is actually two species that dierged between {{ma|2.3}} and {{ma|6.0}}.{{cite journal |doi=10.1126/sciadv.1501486 |pmid=26989785 |pmc=4788485 |title=Hidden in plain sight: Cryptic and endemic malaria parasites in North American white-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus) |journal=Science Advances |volume=2 |issue=2 |pages=e1501486 |year=2016 |last1=Martinsen |first1=Ellen S |last2=McInerney |first2=Nancy |last3=Brightman |first3=Heidi |last4=Ferebee |first4=Ken |last5=Walsh |first5=Tim |last6=McShea |first6=William J |last7=Forrester |first7=Tavis D |last8=Ware |first8=Lisa |last9=Joyner |first9=Priscilla H |last10=Perkins |first10=Susan L |last11=Latch |first11=Emily K |last12=Yabsley |first12=Michael J |last13=Schall |first13=Joseph J |last14=Fleischer |first14=Robert C }} The phyogenetic tree suggests that the genus ''[[Nycteria]]'' belongs in a clade that contains the lizard and bird species, that ''Polychromophilus'' form a clade with ''P. odocoilei'' and that ''[[Hepatocystis]]'' species in bats forms a clade with the primate and rodent species. It also suggests that the closest relation to ''Plasmodium'' - other than ''Nycteria'', ''Polychromophilus'' and ''Hepatocystis'' - is the subgenus ''[[Haemoproteus|Parahaemaproteus]]'' and that this sugbenus is more closed related to ''Plasmodium'' that to the genus ''[[Haemoproteus]]''. This study suggests that the subgenus ''Vinkeia'' is now in need of revision. Another paper suggests the transfer of the ancestor of ''Plasmodium'' from lizards to bats without passage via birds.{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.ympev.2016.03.004 |pmid=26975691 |title=Diverse sampling of East African haemosporidians reveals chiropteran origin of malaria parasites in primates and rodents |journal=Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution |volume=99 |pages=7–15 |year=2016 |last1=Lutz |first1=Holly L |last2=Patterson |first2=Bruce D |last3=Kerbis Peterhans |first3=Julian C |last4=Stanley |first4=William T |last5=Webala |first5=Paul W |last6=Gnoske |first6=Thomas P |last7=Hackett |first7=Shannon J |last8=Stanhope |first8=Michael J }} A study of ''Nycteria'' suggests that ''Leukocytozoon'' is basal, followed by ''Heamoproteus''.{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.ijpara.2015.01.008 |pmid=25765623 |title=Nycteria parasites of Afrotropical insectivorous bats |journal=International Journal for Parasitology |volume=45 |issue=6 |pages=375–84 |year=2015 |last1=Schaer |first1=Juliane |last2=Reeder |first2=Deeann M |last3=Vodzak |first3=Megan E |last4=Olival |first4=Kevin J |last5=Weber |first5=Natalie |last6=Mayer |first6=Frieder |last7=Matuschewski |first7=Kai |last8=Perkins |first8=Susan L }} The sister group to ''Plasmodium''/''Nycteria''/''Polychromophilus''/''Hepatocystis'' is ''Paraheamaproteus''. ''Hepatocystis'' appears to be a derived clade arising from with the subgenus ''Plasmodium''. ''Polychromophilius'' is more closely related to the bird/lizard group than to the mammal infecting species. ''Nycteria'' is the sister taxon to the genus ''Plasmodium''. The genome of ''[[Haemoproteus tartakovskyi]]'' has been sequenced.{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/gbe/evw081 |pmid=27190205 |pmc=4898798 |title=The Genome of ''Haemoproteus'' tartakovskyiand Its Relationship to Human Malaria Parasites |journal=Genome Biology and Evolution |volume=8 |issue=5 |pages=1361–73 |year=2016 |last1=Bensch |first1=Staffan |last2=Canbäck |first2=Björn |last3=Debarry |first3=Jeremy D |last4=Johansson |first4=Tomas |last5=Hellgren |first5=Olof |last6=Kissinger |first6=Jessica C |last7=Palinauskas |first7=Vaidas |last8=Videvall |first8=Elin |last9=Valkiūnas |first9=Gediminas }} Its genome (23.2 megabases) is similar in size to those of ''Plasmodium''. Its GC content is 25.4% which is closer to that of ''P. falciparum'' (19.3%) than to ''P. vivax'' (42.3%). Phylogenetic analyses place it as basal to ''Plasmodium'' species. Its inclusion in a phylogenetic tree suggests that the mammalian species are monophytic. A study of 114 mitochondrial genomes from species belonging to four genera - ''[[Haemoproteus]]'', ''[[Hepatocystis]]'', ''[[Leucocytozoon]]'' and ''Plasmodium'' - has shown that like ''Plasmodium'', ''Leucocytozoon'' and ''Haemoproteus'' are not monophyletic taxa.{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/molbev/msx285 |pmid=29126122 |pmc=5850713 |title=Mode and Rate of Evolution of Haemosporidian Mitochondrial Genomes: Timing the Radiation of Avian Parasites |journal=Molecular Biology and Evolution |volume=35 |issue=2 |pages=383–403 |year=2018 |last1=Pacheco |first1=M Andreína |last2=Matta |first2=Nubia E |last3=Valkiūnas |first3=Gediminas |last4=Parker |first4=Patricia G |last5=Mello |first5=Beatriz |last6=Stanley |first6=Craig E |last7=Lentino |first7=Miguel |last8=Garcia-Amado |first8=Maria Alexandra |last9=Cranfield |first9=Michael |last10=Kosakovsky Pond |first10=Sergei L |last11=Escalante |first11=Ananias A }} The estimated times of the divergence of these genera was after the [[Cretaceous]]-[[Paleogene]] boundary (about {{Mya|66}}) and coincided with the evolution of the extant avian orders. The presence of ''[[Plasmodium dominicana]]'' and the related species ''[[Vetufebrus|Vetufebrus ovatus]]'' in Dominican [[amber]] suggests that this genus was present after the [[Cretaceous]]-[[Paleogene]] boundary (about {{Mya|66}}).{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s11230-004-6354-6 |pmid=15928991 |title=''Plasmodium dominicana'' n. sp. (Plasmodiidae: Haemospororida) from Tertiary Dominican amber |journal=Systematic Parasitology |volume=61 |issue=1 |pages=47–52 |year=2005 |last1=Poinar |first1=George }}{{cite journal |doi=10.1186/1756-3305-4-229 |pmid=22152687 |pmc=3253689 |title=''Vetufebrus ovatus'' n. gen., n. sp. (Haemospororida: Plasmodiidae) vectored by a streblid bat fly (Diptera: Streblidae) in Dominican amber |journal=Parasites & Vectors |volume=4 |pages=229 |year=2011 |last1=Poinar |first1=George O }} Although Poinar has suggested a date of ~{{Ma|35}}, the precise dating of Dominican amber is controversial so an exact date for these species cannot currently be safely assigned. Another study found that ''Haemoproteus'' consists of two taxa and that the genus ''Plasmodium'' is paraphyletic with respect to ''Hepatocystis''. The same study also found that ''Plasmodium'' species of mammals form a well supported clade and this clade was associated with specialization to ''[[Anopheles]]'' mosquito vectors. The ''Plasmodium'' of birds and squamate reptiles all fall within a single clade with evidence for repeated switching between birds and squamate hosts. One study using Bayesian factors to identify the root of the phylogenetic tree has suggested that ''Plasmodium'' may be basal to ''Haemoproteus'', ''Leucocytozoon'', ''Paraheamoproteus'' and ''Polychromophilus''. This tree also grouped ''Hepatocystis'' with ''Plasmodium''. ''Rayella'' is thought to have originated from ''Hepatocystis''. A study of the genera ''Hepatocystis'', ''Nycteria'', ''Plasmodium'' and ''Polychromophilus'' found that ''Polychromophilus'' was basal to the other genera and that ''Plasmodium'' and ''Hepatocystis'' were sister clades.{{cite journal |doi=10.1038/s41598-017-07093-z |pmid=28761151 |pmc=5537238 |title=Epauletted fruit bats display exceptionally high infections with a Hepatocystis species complex in South Sudan |journal=Scientific Reports |volume=7 |issue=1 |pages=6928 |year=2017 |last1=Schaer |first1=Juliane |last2=Perkins |first2=Susan L |last3=Ejotre |first3=Imran |last4=Vodzak |first4=Megan E |last5=Matuschewski |first5=Kai |last6=Reeder |first6=Deeann M }} ====Possible evolution==== The evidence suggests the following evolutionary scenario: ''Plasmodium'' evolved from a ''Leucocystis'' like ancestor. This ancestor gave rise to the subgenus ''Parahaemoproteus''. Both of these taxons infect birds. ''Plasmodium'' evolved from its ''Parahaemoproteus'' ancestor when it gained the ability to infect lizards. After this ''Plasmodium'' diverged into a mammal infecting clade and a bird/lizard infecting clade. Within the bird/lizard clade some species developed the ability to infect bats (''Nycteria''). Within the mammalian clade a number of species have also developed the ability to infect bats (''Hepatocystis''). Since ''Haemoproteus'' evolved after the evolution of birds this would suggest that an upper limit for the evolution of this genus is approximately {{ma|66}}. The ''[[Columbidae]]'' - hosts of the ''Haemoproteus'' species - evolved in South East Asia. It is possible that this also was the origin of the genus ''Haemoproteus''. This upper limit may be further reduced. The genus ''Leucocytozoon'' is thought to have evolved in the [[Oligocene]].{{cite journal | last1 = Bennett | first1 = GF | year = 1993 | title = Phylogenetic distribution and possible evolution of the avian species of the ''Haemoproteidae'' | url = | journal = Systematic Parasitology| volume = 26 | issue = 1| pages = 39–44 | doi=10.1007/bf00009646}} This would place an upper limit of {{ma|33.9}} for the evolution of the genus ''Leucocytozoon''. This is in agreement with an estimate of the time of the basal radiation of the genus ''Plasmodium''.{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.gene.2012.04.037 |pmid=22555021 |title=Age of the last common ancestor of extant Plasmodium parasite lineages |journal=Gene |volume=502 |issue=1 |pages=36–9 |year=2012 |last1=Hayakawa |first1=Toshiyuki |last2=Tachibana |first2=Shin-Ichiro |last3=Hikosaka |first3=Kenji |last4=Arisue |first4=Nobuko |last5=Matsui |first5=Atsushi |last6=Horii |first6=Toshihiro |last7=Tanabe |first7=Kazuyuki }} This date of origin lies within the range of other estimates suggesting that it is plausible. This suggestion is supported by other analyses.{{cite journal |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0034990 |pmid=22536346 |pmc=3335055 |title=The Origin of Malarial Parasites in Orangutans |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=7 |issue=4 |pages=e34990 |year=2012 |last1=Pacheco |first1=M. F |last6=Jones-Engel |first6=Lisa |last7=Escalante |first7=Ananias A }} ===Relations with non Haemosporidian genera=== The [[Piroplasma]] are usually considered to be the closest relations to the Haemosporidians. Based on the evolution of their vectors ([[tick]]s) they may have evolved ~{{Ma|300}}.{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.meegid.2012.07.004 |pmid=22871652 |title=Babesia: A world emerging |journal=Infection, Genetics and Evolution |volume=12 |issue=8 |pages=1788–809 |year=2012 |last1=Schnittger |first1=Leonhard |last2=Rodriguez |first2=Anabel E |last3=Florin-Christensen |first3=Monica |last4=Morrison |first4=David A }} The vectors of ''Babesia'' and ''Theileria'' - ticks - evolved {{Ma|350}} ± {{Ma|23}}.{{cite journal |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0049461 |pmid=23145176 |pmc=3493528 |title=The Mitochondrial Genomes of Nuttalliella namaqua (Ixodoidea: Nuttalliellidae) and Argas africolumbae (Ixodoidae: Argasidae): Estimation of Divergence Dates for the Major Tick Lineages and Reconstruction of Ancestral Blood-Feeding Characters |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=7 |issue=11 |pages=e49461 |year=2012 |last1=Mans |first1=Ben J |last2=De Klerk |first2=Daniel |last3=Pienaar |first3=Ronel |last4=De Castro |first4=Minique H |last5=Latif |first5=Abdalla A }} The hard ([[Ixodidae]]) and soft bodied ([[Argasidae]]) ticks diverged {{Ma|290}}± {{Ma|23}}. The most likely place of origin of the ticks is Northern [[Gondwana]] and most probably within the region that now constitutes Eastern [[Africa]]. A molecular Bayesian study of ''[[Babesia]]'' and ''[[Theileria]]'' species along with ''Plasmodium'' species suggests that ''Babesia'' and ''Theileria'' are sister clades and that they diverged from ''Plasmodium'' ~{{Ma|56.5}} (95% credible interval: {{Ma|86.9}} - {{Ma|28.2}}){{cite journal |doi=10.1002/ece3.685 |pmid=24101988 |pmc=3790545 |title=Coevolutionary analyses of the relationships between piroplasmids and their hard tick hosts |journal=Ecology and Evolution |volume=3 |issue=9 |pages=2985–93 |year=2013 |last1=Gou |first1=Huitian |last2=Guan |first2=Guiquan |last3=Liu |first3=Aihong |last4=Ma |first4=Miling |last5=Chen |first5=Ze |last6=Liu |first6=Zhijie |last7=Ren |first7=Qiaoyun |last8=Li |first8=Youquan |last9=Yang |first9=Jifei |last10=Yin |first10=Hong |last11=Luo |first11=Jianxun }} The dating in this study used a date of {{Ma|12.5}} for the origin of the genus ''Plasmodium''. The authors also estimated that ''Theileria'' evolved {{Ma|23.38}} (95% credible interval {{Ma|11.1}} – {{Ma|36.7}}) and that ''Babesia'' evolved {{Ma|25.7}} (95% credible interval {{Ma|12.8}}–{{Ma|40.7}}) Another analysis suggests that ''[[Babesia]]'' and ''[[Theileria]]'' are more closely related to the adeleid species than to ''Plasmodium''.{{cite journal |doi=10.2307/3282766 |pmid=2494316 |jstor=3282766 |title=Phylogenetic Analysis of the Class Sporozoea (Phylum Apicomplexa Levine, 1970): Evidence for the Independent Evolution of Heteroxenous Life Cycles |journal=The Journal of Parasitology |volume=75 |issue=2 |pages=195–206 |year=1989 |last1=Barta |first1=John R }} An examination of sequences from ''[[Babesiidae]]'', ''[[Cryptosporiidae]]'', ''[[Eimeriidae]]'', ''Plasmodiidae'', ''[[Sarcocystiidae]]'', ''[[Theileriidae]]'', a ''[[Perkinsus]]'' species and 2 [[dinoflagellate]]s suggests that ''Plasmodium'' and ''Cryptosporidium'' are sister taxa and that ''[[Hepatozoon]]'' is basal to them.{{cite journal |doi=10.1645/0022-3395(2000)086[0366:PROHAA]2.0.CO;2 |pmid=10780559 |year=2000 |volume=86 |issue=2 |pages=366–72 |title=Phylogenetic Relationships Ofhepatozoon(Apicomplexa: Adeleorina) Based on Molecular, Morphologic, and Life-Cycle Characters |journal=Journal of Parasitology |last1=Mathew |first1=J. An analysis of the rodent genera (''[[Plasmodium berghei]]'', ''[[Plasmodium chabaudi]]'', ''[[Plasmodium vinckei]]'' and ''[[Plasmodium yoelii]]'') suggests that these species may actually be species complexes. The separation of ''P. chabaudi'' and ''P. vinckei'' has been estimated to be between {{Mya|3}} and {{Mya|13}} while that of ''P. berghei'' and ''P. yoelii'' has been placed at {{Mya|1}} and {{Mya|6}}. A paper that included five unnamed lemur species suggested that ''P. ovale'' is more closely related to the lemur species than to the other primate ones. It also suggested that the lemur/''P. ovale'' clade is a sister clade of the rodent species. While this is consistent with the placement of the lemur and rodent species in the subgenus ''Vinckeia'' it is inconsistent with the current placement of ''P. ovale'' within the subgenus ''Plasmodium''. This paper also supports a basal divergence within the mammalian species into the subgenus ''Laverinia'' and the others. The subgenera ''Plasmodium'' and ''Vinckeia'' with the exception of ''P. ovale'' appear to be sister clades. Analysis of the apicoplast genes auggests that ''P. ovale'' is related to the rodent species.{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/molbev/mss082 |pmid=22396524 |title=The Plasmodium Apicoplast Genome: Conserved Structure and Close Relationship of P. This paper confirms the groupings found elsewhere with an Asian clade. The rodent species seem to be more closely related to the ''Laverania'' subgenus than does the subgenus ''Plasmodium''. A deletion mutation of ~100 base pairs including part of the [[LS1 rRNA]] gene is found in the sequences of two African species - ''P. gonderi'' and an undescribed parasite taken from a mandrill - and 2 Asian species - ''P. cynomolgi'' and ''P. simiovale''. This mutation was not found in the other species examined (''[[Leucocytozoon caulleryi]]'', ''[[Leucocytozoon sabrazesi]]'', ''P. bergei'', ''P. chabaudi'', ''P. falciparum'', ''P. floridense'', ''P. gallacium'', ''P. fragile'', ''P. juxtanucleare'', ''P. knowelsi'', ''P. mexicanum'', ''P. reichenowi'', ''P. relictum'', ''P. simiae'', ''P. vivax'', ''P. yoelii'' and two unnamed ''[[Haemoproteus]]'' species.) These mutations are rare events and strongly suggests these species are related. Another paper suggests that after the mammalian-reptile/bird species split that the subgenus ''Laverina'' is basal among the mammal species.{{cite journal |doi=10.1371/journal.ppat.1000765 |pmid=20169187 |pmc=2820532 |title=On the Diversity of Malaria Parasites in African Apes and the Origin of Plasmodium falciparum from Bonobos |journal=PLoS Pathogens |volume=6 |issue=2 |pages=e1000765 |year=2010 |last1=Krief |first1=Sabrina |last2=Escalante |first2=Ananias A |last3=Pacheco |first3=M.
